headline: Ohio, KY governors seek federal funding to build new bridge next to Brent Spence without tolls
author: WLWT Digital Staff
sentences:
“Not only will this project improve quality of life for drivers in Ohio and Kentucky, but keeping this major transportation network open and moving will also have a significant positive impact on our national economy and national security.”
The bridge is a major source of congestion and frustration for drivers and has long been considered functionally obsolete, handling more traffic than it was built for.

And just as important: This project shows what we in government can do when we embrace cooperation and progress and simply do what is best for our people.”
“For decades, the backups on the Brent Spence Bridge have frustrated drivers, hindered economic development and slowed supply chain deliveries.

The teams at the Kentucky Transportation Cabinet and Ohio Department of Transportation have been planning the Brent Spence Bridge Corridor Project for nearly two decades, completing the critical groundwork that has made this project nearly shovel-ready.

The Brent Spence Bridge is safe and structurally sound and will serve a critical transportation need for decades to come.”
“The signing of this document is a very clear and public show of action by both states,” said Jack Marchbanks, director of ODOT.
Today, a solution is in reach, and we are committed to aggressively working together to secure this funding to help us fix this transportation nightmare once and for all,” DeWine said in a statement.
“This memorandum spells out our obligations and positions us to quickly apply for these federal dollars, which will allow us not only to build this new bridge, but to do it without tolls.

COVINGTON, Ky. —
The governors of Ohio and Kentucky announced Monday they are requesting up to $2 billion to drastically improve the congestion and traffic on the Brent Spence Bridge.
If awarded to Kentucky and Ohio, the funds would primarily be used to build a new companion bridge over the Ohio River to give drivers an alternative to the Brent Spence Bridge.
“New funding will support the construction of a new bridge – not a replacement – as well as updates to the existing bridge and the interstate network throughout the corridor.
Andy Beshear announced plans to request up to $2 billion in funding from the U.S. Department of Transportation for the long-discussed Brent Spence Bridge Corridor Project.
“With today’s signing, the commonwealth of Kentucky and the state of Ohio are aligning our efforts to make this project a reality,” Beshear said in a statement.
The bridge was built in the 1960s to carry around 80,000 vehicles a day, but the daily traffic load has reached 160,000 vehicles in recent years.
“This critical step will help be competitive in the federal grant process and will allow the bi-state team to start moving this project forward.”
And then last year, a maintenance project to clean and paint the bridge resulted in ramp and lane closures for eight months.
The funding is part of the bipartisan federal infrastructure bill, which includes at least $39 billion for bridge projects.
Because of this previous planning, project construction could potentially begin in 2024 if funding is received.
The governors signed a memorandum of understanding that confirms the states will work together on the project.
The memorandum also directs transportation officials in both states to begin preparations for construction.
“The Brent Spence Bridge is the critical link in this important corridor,” KYTC Secretary Jim Gray said.
Then, in November 2020, a fiery crash set the bridge on fire, shutting down all traffic for weeks.
Beshear said he wants to break ground next year, saying "It's time."
A more detailed interstate agreement will be signed later this year.
Talk of replacing the bridge stalled when the pandemic hit.
